text: Okay, so if you're feeling lost when it comes to vocal production and you don't know how to get your vocals to sound as good as the Spotify Top 50, or the stuff that you hear on the radio, or your favorite pop singers or rappers or whatever, then you are in the right place.

I've been a professional producer, mixing engineer and mastering engineer for over a decade now, and I have a system for producing vocals that's going to get your vocals to sound incredible, whether you're processing your own or somebody else's.
And the best part is the system works whether you're using stock plugins, or you have a bunch of third party stuff that you want to use.
So first, I'm going to explain what the system is, and then we're going to jump into Ableton, and I'm going to show you exactly how to process vocals using stock Ableton plugins.
And then I'm going to show you my professional vocal chain that I've spent the last 10 years perfecting.
But first, let's go to the iPad so I can teach you the concept. It'll only take a couple minutes, and it's going to help you so much. Trust me.
The way I like to think about processing vocals is we're going to build a vocal processing chain from the ground up. And it's only four layers.
The first layer is going to look like this. And that is going to be compression.
So that's our base layer. That's the first thing we're going to do when we're processing vocals. We're going to add compression.
Now the next step after that is going to be EQ, which stands for equalization. So compression, EQ.
Then after that, we have de-essing. Compression, EQ, de-essing. And the last step is we're going to compress again.
Let me just color this in really quick.
Okay, so there you have it. I like to call this the compression sandwich. And it's just an easy way to remember how to process vocals.
You get your vocals, you put compression on them, then you EQ them, then you de-ess them, and then you compress them again.
The reason I did a burger or a compression sandwich is so you could actually remember this no matter what DAW you're using.
You can do this with Logic, FL Studio, Pro Tools. But right now I'm going to show you exactly how to do it in Ableton.
And I think you'll be really surprised and really impressed with just how close Ableton stock plugins come to sounding like the expensive third party plugins.
So no excuses. You can get your vocals to sound incredible using this method. If you're following along, go ahead and open up Ableton and I'll meet you on the computer.

Hardly noticeable difference, but the reason why we're compressing initially is because when you compress, you limit a signal's dynamic range,
meaning that the quiet parts are louder than the other parts.
And it kind of just squishes everything more in the middle.
So this is just to make the vocal more consistent.
And these quiet parts like this, you are going to be a bit louder.
And these loud parts like this, my are going to be a bit quieter.
Okay, so now we have some basic compression going.

So as far as vocals go, we don't need any sub bass frequencies, meaning we don't need anything from like 80 to 100 Hertz and lower.
So what we can do is go to the left and click on the EQ.
So what we can do is click on this one here on the EQ, click on the arrow and make sure it's a high pass filter and then drag that up to around 100 Hertz.
Or if you want to be aggressive, you can click on the times four.
That'll just make it really aggressive.

So when you first open Ableton, you're going to have two send tracks right here and you can use these to send the vocal to some reverb, which is going to be down here on these return tracks.
So if we turn this up, you'll hear some reverb going on the vocal.
And the reason we want to do reverb like this is because this is going to have 100% of the vocal signal and then it's going to put reverb on top of that.
We could drag reverb directly onto this vocal track and just put it right after the rest of our effects.
But the problem is if I drag a reverb onto it, anytime I'm turning up this dry wet, it's actually making the vocal quieter and it's turning up the reverb.
But if we do it this way by using the sends, the vocal stays at the same volume and adds reverb to it.
Okay, that's sounding pretty good.

I usually just click on Mastering Vocal De-Essing in Music and play with it from there.

and then you utilize that automation technique with the utility.
